title: How many cases of COVID-19 will be reported by the Africa CDC as of 1 April 2021?
possible_answers: More than 5.0 million but fewer than 10.0 million
preds: A little late to this question, but better late than never.
There is still fewer than 5 million cases on the 31st of March.

Probability: 99% between 2.5 million and 5 million, 1% more than 5 million but fewer than 10 million As of 5 March 2021, the Africa CDC reports 3,948,029 confirmed cases of COVID-19, resulting in a 0% 
chance that there will be fewer than 2.5 million cases reported as of 1 April 2021. From 29 December
2020 (2.6 million cases) to yesterday (3.9 million cases), there has been an increase of approximately 1.3 
million cases over 9 weeks, which averages to around 145,000 per week. If that average continues, an 
additional 580,000 cases will be reported by 1 April 2021, bringing the total to an estimated 4,528,029 
cases (“Coronavirus Disease 2019”). The number of daily new infections reported in Africa appears to be decreasing, after peaking in late 
January. According to the Reuters COVID-19 tracker, Africa saw 36,173 new infections on 9 January 
2021. Rates had dropped to 11,051 new infections on 8 February and 7,956 new infections on 5 March,
continuing a downward trend in the reporting of new COVID-19 cases (“Africa”). According to Time Magazine, Africa may have unique factors that contribute to the decrease in reported 
numbers of cases. These include an average age of 19 years old and an overall smaller population of 
people over the age of 50 when compared with other countries. As COVID seems to affect older
populations more than younger, this would indicate lower rates of infection will continue. “The fact that 
diabetes, obesity and hypertension, some of the comorbidities that appear to make COVID-19 more 
deadly, are also less common among the continent’s population than they are in other parts of the
world” also accounts for a projected decline in the number of reported cases (Baker). Taking the above factors into consideration, I forecast that there is a 99% chance that there will be 
between 2.5 million and 5 million cases as of 1 April 2021. There is a 1% chance that there will be more 
than 5 fewer than 10 million cases, a 0% chance that there will be between 10 and 20 million cases, and 
0% chance that there will be more than more than 20 million cases. Sources: “Africa.” Reuters Covid-19 Tracker. https://graphics.reuters.com/world-coronavirus-tracker-andmaps/regions/africa/. Accessed March 6, 2021. Baker, Aryn. “Why Africa's COVID-19 Outbreak Hasn't Been as Bad as Everyone Feared.” Time. 
December 30, 2020. https://www.time.com/5919241/africa-covid-19-outbreak/. Accessed March 4, 
2021. “Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19).” Africa CDC. https://www.africacdc.org/covid-19/. Accessed 
March 6, 2021.

My conclusion is based on a few different factors. After comparing the rate of change across various countries, reading into the situation in South Africa, and studying up on the deployment of the relatively effective J&J vaccine, I highly doubt that the African CDC will report more than 5.0 million cases on April 1st.

There are already almost 4 million confirmed cases in Africa at this time. So having fewer than 2.5 million is impossible. Due to the vaccine roll out the number of daily confirmed cases will start to decrease. The total new daily cases in South Africa are around 1,300. Around 38% of the cases in Africa are in South Africa. It took around 8 months for the total confirmed cases to reach 1 million in South Africa. There would need to be 1.1 million new cases in the next 25 days for the total confirmed cases to reach over 5 million. With the vaccine rollout, I do not believe that the number of new cases will reach 1.1 million.

As of March 5, 2021 the Africa CDC has reported 3,948,029 cases of Covid-19.  This number alone means there is a 0% chance that fewer than 2.5 million cases could be reported.  1,051,972 more cases would need to be reported to cross the 5.0 million, inclusive, threshold, and with only 24 days left until the April 1, 2021 deadline, it is not improbable, but highly unlikely. So, I have predicted a 2% chance of cases reported being more than 5.0 million but fewer than 10.0 million.  “There are wide variations in testing rates and while some countries have reduced testing, others have maintained or even increased it at different points during the pandemic” (Mwai 2021).  The lack of a consistent rate of testing across the continent means that cases which are still to be reported are only going to come out of large countries that have increased testing, such as South Africa.  “For Epi week 8 (22 - 28 February 2021), 67,608 new COVID-19 cases have been reported, which is a 10% decrease in the number of new cases reported compared to Epi week 7” (Africa CDC).  To reach 1,051,972 new reported cases in 24 days, 43,832 cases would have to be reported daily.  The rate of reporting appears to be around 9,660 cases daily. This leads me to predict that cases reported will not rise above 5.0 million inclusive by April 1, 2021, so I am predicting a 98% chance that the number will remain between 2.5 million and 5.0 million.  Africa CDC. (2021). Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19). https://africacdc.org/covid-19/
Africa CDC. (2021). Outbreak Brief 59: Coronavirus Disease 2019 (Covid-19) Pandemic. https://africacdc.org/download/outbreak-brief-59-coronavirus-disease-2019-covid-19-pandemic/
Mwai, P. (2021). Coronavirus: Africa’s new variants are causing growing concern. BBC. https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-53181555

As of March 5, 2021, the total cumulative number of COVID-19 cases in Africa is 3,948,029 cases (Africa CDC, 2021). Therefore there is 0% chance of there being fewer than 2.5 million cases at any point in the future. To get my estimate for April 1st, 2021, I calculated the number of weekly cases over the last month, and the number of monthly cases over the last 8 months. Based on stats from the Milken Institute | COVID-19 Africa Watch (2021), I got the following: Week of:	Number of COVID-19 cases reported that week:
01/11/2021: 	+203,123 cases
01/04/2021: 	+226,883 cases
12/28/2020: 	+158,223 cases
12/21/2020: 	+162,371 cases Increase in cases in 1 month:
Dec-Jan, 2021: +750,600 cases
Nov-Dec, 2020: +379,511 cases
Sept-Oct, 2020: +216,713 cases
July-Aug, 2020: +452,782 cases Factoring in most recent stats: from January 4, 2021 (2,830,099 cases reported), to March 5, 2021 (3,948,029 cases reported), there was an increase of 1,117,930 cases (Milken Institute | COVID-19 Africa Watch, 2021; Africa CDC, 2021). Taking averages of these numbers over the last 8 months, you get an increase of roughly 434,000 cases per month. On the recent high end, there’s an average increase of roughly 188,000 cases per week (taken beginning of December - beginning of January). On the recent low end, there’s an average increase of roughly 140,000 cases per week (taken beginning of January - beginning of March) With a low weekly prediction, Africa would land at about 4.5 million cumulative COVID-19 cases on 04/01/2021. With a high weekly prediction, it would be at about 4.7 million cases. Based on monthly averages, Africa CDC would report about 4.4 million cases as of 04/01/2021. Because it is not 100% impossible for Africa CDC to report more than 20.0 million cases (as compared to reporting fewer than 2.5 million cases), I am therefore giving 1% probability to that statistic. Between 10.0 million and 20.0 million, inclusive, is a bit more probable, but still incredibly unlikely, so I am therefore giving it 4%. Africa CDC. (2021). Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19). https://africacdc.org/covid-19/
Milken Institute | COVID-19 Africa Watch. (2021). Data & Charts. https://covid19africawatch.org/data-and-charts/

According to BBC World reporting, there are currently 3.9 plus reported cases of Covid-19 on the continent of Africa. While Africa has historically done very well with maintaining a low rate of cases and high success with health security measures, the recent spike in cases and spread are threatening an already weak health care system. Taking this into consideration, it does not seem unlikely that cases will rise to a number between 5-10 million, but with current safety measures remaining in place, it would be unlikely that they would skyrocket to numbers between 10-20 million.  https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-53181555
https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-54418613

Africa has experienced two spikes in COVID cases since March 2020 when the pandemic began. In late July, 2020, nearly 20K cases were reported. This was followed by a downward trend that ended in October. The next spike occurred in January, 2021 with 30K cases reported. Since then, there is a downward trend of cases with 7.3K reported in Mar, 2021. If the second spike is followed by a similar downward trend, then cases will decrease over a roughly 3 month period, which would result in an increase in cases in April. The rate of falling case counts from January's spike to March 3rd ranged from 226 to 707 per day. This makes for an average falling case rate of 469.75. However, the downward trend is curved not linear with the cases reducing by 50% approximately every 30 days over a 3 x month period of decline. On Mar 2, 7.3K cases were reported, hence by April 1, approximately 3.65k cases will be reported. The number of cases reported will fall by roughly 121 per day. With the current case count at 2,854,741, the total number of cases added between 03MAR2021 and 01APR2021 is estimated to be 159,022. Thus the total number of cases in Africa on 01APR2021 is projected to be 3,013,763.

At the time of this forecast (March 5th, 2021) there were close to 4 million reported cases. Comparing the trend of new cases with the availability of testing I don't imagine it will break 5 million before the first of the month. I think the scarcity of test kits on the continent will have the biggest impact on these numbers. I still forecast some percentage into the higher numbers just because I believe while improbable its not impossible.

I assess that there is a 0% chance of the Africa CDC reporting fewer than 2.5 million cases of COVID-19, as the Africa CDC (2021) has reported 3,937,028 cases as of 05MARCH2021. The next category of a threshold is over 5 million reported cases. If we subtract the number of people who have died (105,001) and recovered (3,512,473) from COVID-19 in Africa, that leaves us with the current number of active COVID-19 cases: 319,554 (Africa CDC, 2021). With this number in mind, I then looked at the current infection rate of Africa. Given the first patient reported with COVID-19 in Africa was in Egypt on 14FEBUARY2021 (Al Jazeera, 2020), I divided the total number of reported cases by 12.5 adjusting for the months COVID-19 has been in Africa. This gave me 314,962.24/month. This number is very close to the current amount of 319,554. Given the next bracket being 5 million, COVID-19 would need to infect more than 1 million people within less than a month’s timespan. This infection rate would be more than triple the current pace COVID-19 has had in Africa. Due to this, I do not believe COVID-19 will surpass the 5 million case mark by 01APRIL2021 but will stay between 2.5 million and 5.0 million reported cases by Africa CDC. To track monthly trends, I have made an Excel spreadsheet of all the African countries and will be utilizing the John Hopkins University reports of African countries to spot large-scale increases or decreases in COVID-19, and then see if the African CDC seems to be reporting this.

As of March 3rd, 2021 (4pm EAT), the Africa CDC has reported 3,924,755 cases of COVID-19 infections across the continent and its islands . In total, Central Africa has reported approximately 105.4k cases, Western Africa has reported approximately 393.9k cases, Eastern Africa has reported approximately 411.4k cases, Northern Africa has reported approximately 1.2m cases, and Southern Africa has reported approximately 1.8m cases. In total, there have been 104,672 reported COVID-19 deaths in Africa and 3,501,772 reported recoveries. These numbers are larger than those reported by the WHO Regional Office of Africa . As of March 3rd, 2021 (7pm), the WHO Africa dashboard showed a total of 2,841,248 reported COVID-19 cases, 2,535,223 recoveries, and 72,679 cumulative deaths.  Nearly every country in Africa is experiencing Epidemic phase 3 , with reported new cases decreasing across the continent from previous weeks. Cases in Central Africa increased 23% during week 8 (2/22-2/28) from week 7, cases in Eastern Africa increased 5% during week 8, cases in Norther Africa increased 3% during week 8, cases in Southern Africa decreased (-)18% during week 8, and cases in Western Africa decreased (-)27% during week 8. In total, the number of new reported cases for week 8 decreased (-)10% from week 7. Since the beginning of January 2021, weekly reported COVID-19 cases have been falling . Based on this downward trajectory alone, it might be expected that cases will continue to drop through the month of March. However, outbreaks in most countries are advancing (Phase 3), which means a third wave may occur between now and April. If cases per week level off below/at 10,000, Africa CDC cases might reach close to 4m total cases by April 1st. For WHO Africa, it might reach 2.9m total cases.  With less than a month left till April 1st, 2021, ‘Fewer than 2.5 million’ reported COVID-19 cases has a probability of zero, since Africa has now surpassed 2.5 million on the CDC and WHO reports. The cumulative number of COVID-19 cases I expect Africa to report by April 1st will fall somewhere between 3-5m, therefore I’ll give ‘Between 2.5 million and 5.0 million, inclusive’ a probability score of 80%. In the event a continent-wide third wave occurs during the month of March, I will give ‘More than 5.0 million but fewer than 10.0 million’ a probability score of 20%. It seems unlikely Africa will report over 10m COVID-19 cases between now and April 1st. Therefore, the last two outcomes will be given probability scores of 0%.
The current trends are slowing down and many are on the decline for newly reported cases.  I see it unlikely to see a rapid increase in the next month.

So currently, the Africa CDC has reported 3,914,044 COVID cases, automatically ruling out that there will be fewer than 2.5 million cases as of April 1st, 2021. According to Reuters, on average, there are around 10,500 new cases in Africa each day. This is on a downward slope since its peak at over 31,000 new cases each day in the week of January 10th. There are 28 days between now (March 3rd) and April 1st. Assuming the daily average does not rise in the next month, which looks unlikely given the steady decline over the past month and a half, there will be around 294,000 new cases in the 28 days between now and April 1st. This means that based on these statistics, there will be around 4,208,000 cases reported by the Africa CDC as of April 1st. Even if somehow cases shot back up to a daily average of 31,000 for the rest of March, that would add up to 868,000 cases from now to April 1st, creating an overall total of 4,782,044. Given this, I would say with 100% confidence that the number of cases reported by the Africa CDC by April 1st, 2021 will be between 2.5 million and 5.0 million, inclusive. It is possible by May or June that the case count will jump above 5.0 million, but I do not predict it will do so in the next month.

As of March 2, 2021 Africa has reported 3,914,044 cases. With only 313,280 active COVID-19 Cases in Africa, it seems unlikely that 1,085,956 new cases would be reported in the next 30 days, as that would be approximately 36,198.5 cases per day and Africa is currently reporting a million new infections about every 54 days. Between February 2nd and February 28th only 158,168 new cases were reported, averaging 5,858 per day. South Africa, contributing to over half of total cases, is decreasing with 1,318 new infections reported on average each day.

As of 28 February 2021, the Africa CDC reported 3,897,390 cases of coronavirus on the continent, of which 3,476,050 are listed as recoveries and 103,712 are listed as deaths.  Based on this information, Africa cannot have fewer than 2.5 million cases by 1 April 2021, therefore I have assigned a 0% probability for this outcome as it is impossible.  Since the first case of coronavirus in Africa was declared on 14 February 2020, this indicates an infection rate of approximately 311,791.2 people per month (total cases divided by 12.5 months).  Furthermore, with 317,628 active cases on the continent (total cases minus recoveries and deaths) each infected person would have to spread the virus to approximately 3.5 other people to infect an additional 1,102,610 within the next 31 days, thus breaking the “5 million” threshold to the next category.  Africa appears to have had two peaks in daily infections; one around 23 July 2020 with 19,612 new cases and one around 9 January 2021 with 36,173 new cases, but the current seven-day average appears to be between 10,000 and 10,150.  This rate does not show a significant difference from the average monthly infection rate, however, another spike similar to or greater than the one seen in January 2021 may provide a large enough deviation to surpass 5 million cases.  Since the January 2021 spike was slow growing over several months and the rate of infection is currently on a decline, it is unlikely that it would occur with enough speed to reach this number within the next 31 days.  Based on this information, I assess there is a 2% chance the number of cases could reach 5 million by 1 April 2021, and it is a certainty that it will not exceed 10 million cases within the same amount of time.  It is almost certain (98%) the cases will remain between the current number and 5 million by 1 March 2021.
Africa remains one of the many mysteries around COVID.  Not following the trends and patterns in the rest of the world.

The new daily infection rate is dropping slightly, but overall for the last month or so has remained roughly the same as different countries are in different stages of the pandemic.  There are already more then 2.5 million and the chances of hitting 5 million are decreasing to 0 very quickly.  Based on recent trends it should be around 4.5 million on 4/1.

As of 31 December 2020 Africa-CDC reported 2,759,313 cases this leaves us with exactly 90 days and 2 240 687 cases for it to go past the five million mark, which equates to a sustained rate of 24 896 cases per day While the current daily average has been higher than that it should be noted that it has been driven by a surge in one  country, South Africa. A rise in cases was spotted in November, by mid December they were hitting 10K cases per day, then 14K cases and ended the New Year with 18K cases. This increase is most likely from what might be termed a Holiday surge, lots of super spreader events, parties and ppl generally letting their guard down and the 501v.2 variant

They imposed tougher lock down restrictions on the 28th of December, there is also a concern that the 501v.2 variant will worsen the situation, although there seems to be some evidence that this may not be the case. The Eastern Cape were the 501v.2 broke out hit a daily high of 19K active cases, it has since gone down to just below 5K active cases and then up to 7323 with the holiday surge. The Western Cape and KZN have also shown step rises in the number of active cases (42K and 55K respectively) but despite the holiday surge their numbers have not seen a dramatic increase.  With the effect of the lock down restrictions expected to kick in soon cases numbers should start to decline, which means the total daily figures for Africa will go down as well. While this has not happened with lineage B.1.1.7  in the UK it may well be down to two factors, firstly 501v.2 is not as infectious and also it is summer in the Southern hemisphere

Cases in Egypt has seen a rise over the last few weeks, but they and a few other African countries will be implementing a vaccine program. South Africa may only start on a vaccine program by April, although they could locally manufacture the AZ Oxford Vax earlier. Either way with only 90 days to go I do not think this will have much effect on the outcome of this question Cases are increasing as a whole in a number of countries , it is not clear yet that the 501v.2 or another variant like lineage B.1.1.7  will cause volumes to increase substantially, but is a possibility that cannot be discounted Nigeria has seen a small increase in cases for the month of December, but on the whole have remained stable

Sorry for delay, have been waiting for A-CDC to release figures for 21 December, also work is coming in, there is shopping to do, plus communicating is not my forte  There are now exactly 100 Days to go. As of the 21 December Africa CDC recorded 2 526 520 cases over the 265 day period. The question is how many cases can occur within the 100 days that remain

Let us look at the factors, we know that we are dealing with exponential growth, so numbers will be increasing at a faster rate until a break point is hit. An additional factor is the introduction of the 501v variant which is more infectious and has given rise to increasing numbers in South Africa Daily cases for the continent have increased from a average of 8K per day in September, then 9.5 in October, followed by 13.5K in November. December has been a bit a roller coaster, Morocco was coming out of its peak, Tunisia numbers had increased during November and have not gone down a lot, then 501v made SA numbers jump through the roof, so I would rather use a working average of 18.5K for December. One needs to bear in mind that at the start of December Morocco was coming off a average of 4.5K and SA was about 2.2K  -  This has now turned around to were Morocco are about 2.5K and SA up to about 9K and increasing In the short term I would expect Morocco’s figures to drop, while SA figures might continue to rise due to the more infectious 501v variant.  There is however a change that I am seeing in the pattern that makes me wonder if there will be a continuous explosion in numbers.  Last time around the surge started in the Western Cape (WC) followed by the Eastern Cape (EC) then Kwa Zulu Natal (KZN) and onto Gauteng, then the rest of the country / provinces.  This time around there appears to be a difference, it started out in the EC with the 501v variant, then went to the WC and then onto KZN   Now it is currently starting up in Gauteng   There is however something odd going on, while cases were increasing rapidly in the WC and KZN they have started to flatten out in the EC  -  There could be various reasons for this, but it may be part of a trend, so I will be keeping a close watch on both in the near future

With 2 473 480 cases in 100 Days the Maths are fairly simple, it will require a sustained rate of 24.7K cases per day to take us to the next bucket. If we look at the history of the growth in numbers and also the nature of this infection, it would seem quite possible that this figure could be reached. The introduction of a faster spreading variant/s, in this case 501v is indeed a tool that should be used in modelling However…  There remains a few problems, while it seems possible that the numbers could well increase, will they be counted? Can the health care systems in the affected countries cope with the sheer number of cases?  This is something that was spotted when working on the forecast for China earlier this year, were you had Lab test cases, suspected cases and unexplained deaths. The sad truth of the situation is for a lot of these countries there are finite resources and personnel. Studying some of the data I do not think SA could handle more than 200 – 250K active cases for a sustained period of time. The two countries with the highest number of tests have the highest number of cases (SA & Morocco) Out of the 57 countries in Africa only five have done more than a million tests and only seven others have done more than half a million tests  (SA 6M  -  Morocco 4M  -  Ethiopia 1.7M  -  Egypt 1M  -  Kenya  1M) Looking at the difference between the UK and SA it should be noted that it is winter in the UK temperatures are low and they are only getting about 8 hours sunlight per day, in SA it is summer. While people tend to down play the part that weather may play, it might be the one thing that could help.  The News in the UK about the concern of the possible spread of 501v there is in itself very worrying  Nigeria and Egypt have seen an increase in cases but seem stable for now

In conclusion it seems there is a greater possibility that it may well go over the 5 Million mark by April, what happens in the next three weeks will be critical

Outlook in a nutshell
01 November the total number of cases stood at 1 794 507 as of 01 December the number was  2 187 417 an increase of 392 910  There are now four months to go (121 days)  Current daily infection rate is about 13.5K  -  Morocco which was a factor in the rise in numbers appears to be dropping and could level out over the next two weeks. Two calculations I ran saw the 2.5 Million point would be reached by about 21 December,  This would then leave exactly 100 days to reach the next target of 2.5 Million which would require a sustained rate of 25K cases per day The main drivers of numbers for November were Morocco (137 252)  South Africa (64 552) and Tunisia (35 654) South Africa appears to be increasing with cases and Rt numbers rising in two provinces (Western and Eastern Cape)  They have not reported test numbers for four days, the case to test percentage is useful in seeing if there is a increasing or decreasing trend, for example when Morocco were recording 5K+ cases per day the test to positive rate was 20 – 25% they are now recording less cases and accordingly the rate has gone down to about 17%  -  South Africa had risen from 8% test to case to over 10%  this tied in with the rise in numbers Madagascar with a Population of 28M is the lowest with only 373 cases in November (they like to Move it, move it)

It would be easy to say that it looks like it will take eight and a half months to reach 2.5 Million and for it to reach another 2.5 Million in three and a half months seems a bit of a tall task, but not impossible, given the nature of the infection. On the other hand how many cases can any one country cope with per day? South Africa were swamped at 15K cases, they could possibly handle more now having been down that track, but not more than 20K and not for any sustained amount of time

One needs to keep an eye on when the first 2.5 Million mark will be reached,  my feeling is it might only come in at about 26 December. I am inclined to go along with the cold theory, being based in Africa I can personally confirm there have been some really bad cases of colds (Not Flu) going around the last few years   Coronavirus in Africa: Overcrowding might explain mystery of low death rate
Andrew Harding  BBC Africa  03 September 2020 As the number of infections dips sharply in South Africa, and stays relatively low across much of the continent, experts are reaching towards a startling hypothesis. For months health experts have been warning that living conditions in poor, urban communities across Africa are likely to contribute to a rapid spread of coronavirus.  In the early stages of the pandemic, all the experts and all the modelling agreed that Africa was in trouble "I thought we were heading towards a disaster, a complete meltdown," said Professor Shabir Madhi, South Africa's top virologist.  South Africa has still performed impressively well, as have many other parts of the continent, where hospital beds remain stubbornly empty, and where infection graphs have almost entirely avoided the pronounced peaks and sharp angles seen in so many other parts of the world. "Most African countries don't have a peak. I don't understand why. I'm completely at sea," admitted Prof Karim The idea is that, by studying the PBMCs, the scientists might find evidence that people had been widely infected by other coronaviruses - those, for instance, responsible for many common colds - and that, as a result, they might enjoy some degree of immunity to Covid-19. "I can't think of anything else that would explain the numbers of completely asymptomatic people we're seeing. The numbers are completely unbelievable," he said, savouring the irony of the possibility that Africa's entrenched poverty might "for once" work in the continent's favour. https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-53998374

This is kind of three questions really: 1) Until April 21, will Africa suffer the disease Covid-19 as much as India or South America, or mainly the economic consequences like reduced commodity demand and a collapse in trade and aid?, 2) to which degree will Covid-19 cases be reported (on or outside a spectrum from >50% like Switzerland to <10% like India), and 3) if so, will it be contained somewhat similarly to other continents, or continue unabatedly as the unofficial economy represents a far larger share of overall activity and people simply cannot be locked down as they depend on day-by-day income?  So far, around 1% of the population of South Africa have had Covid-19. Daily cases have been falling, but I am assuming an average of 7k/day until April for argument's sake. Then, 3.7% of South African will have been reported as Covid-19 cases by time of resolution. Now I assume that the rest of Africa will see half the infection rate (of the incremental 2.7%) and half the rate of reporting, there would be 7.5 million reported cases outside SA for a 9 million total. That is my base case. If we continue to accrue daily Covid-19 cases without any additional growth, it is still unlikely to get us below 2.5 million (already had 1 million).  Even if Covid-19 spread to the 50-70% of the global population until the end of 2021 as expected by some, it is highly unlikely that more than 2% of all Africans show up in the statistic until 1 April, given the experience elsewhere (like 20% for NYC and 10% or so in India).

Reasons
1. The virus has not behaved consistently from country to country or even regions within a country.
2. So there is very little to extrapolate from as of June 2020. One has to base any early assumptions (july 2020) on understanding conditions that might affect the spread in Africa and its different regions.
3. While spread in Africans in general may not be enhanced by the factors seen in the west, like: preexisting conditions such as obesity, hyper tension etc. Instead in Africa it will be effected dispropotionatly by malnutrition, urban slums, lack of basic hygiene in large parts of the population, extreme density and lack of ability to quarantine in many of the cities, and the lack of adequate ICU units in even major city will be contributing factors across most of the continent. 
4. Africa has managed to keep it numbers down by an early shut down that most African countries adopted and the stop in tourism also helped to keep the virus count down..
5. African countries can not simply remain lockdown for much longer and starve its population. Plus it lacks the resources for the govt to feed them with a locked down economy, for more than a few months. 
6. Fall and Winter is the peak tourism period, as some countries open up for tourism esp from china and EU where the numbers are low right now, the numbers in Africa will pick up fast.
7. Therefore once the lockdowns in these countries are lifted, which they have to be lifted in a couple of months to literally survive, the factors that make Africa vulnerable will be exposed.
8. With a population of 1.2 Billion even a 2% would be around 22 million. The US with all its resources is expected to exceed 1% by Fall.. 
9. The final factor to consider is. In the absence of the ability to conduct large scale testing of even the dead. What assumptions will the African CDC use to calculate the number of cases across such a vastly varied continent, where basic testing is a luxury ? 
10. Based on how off they have been with their early assumptions with countries like India and Brazil which showed no early signs of contagion but have since exponentially gone up, CDC will take those two factors into account an err on the side of a grossly conservative high estimate. 
11. They will err on the side of a high estimate, also to keep the African countries from opening up too early unless there is a treatment or vaccine by then, which is a extremely low probability based on the history of vaccines.
12. What that tells me is that the total number of cases being higher than 2% of the population is extremely likely. And even if the CDC goes with a more conservative estimate it will not be fewer than 20 M.

I could see good explanations for why there would be only 2 million cases up to 200 million cases by April next year. I think environmental/living factors (household sizes, interconnectedness between population hubs, population density, etc.) are more important than the wealth/resources of African countries. African has very capable public health systems, and clearly a country's GDP is not very reflective of their ability to control Covid-19. I expect Africa may fare better than other continents: sparser, hotter, familiar with novel infections, distributed community-based healthcare, and by being late they have more knowledge of how the spread of this infection can be stopped/slowed (it doesn't seem like any country has actually learnt anything from other countries' failures, though). With this in mind, I have favoured lower numbers. The fact that Africa is later than others is probably because it is less connected with the rest of the world, but may also be due to the virus' inability to spread as well here. The WHO predicts 250 million people will catch it over the first year of the pandemic. When I looked into this in March for European countries, the unconfirmed cases were between 10 and 300 times larger than the number of confirmed cases, which isn't particularly helpful! I'll place 5% on >25 million confirmed cases with this information, though. Looking at the virus from a continental perspective is super interesting, Europe's trajectory is markedly different to the others (it looks logistic while the others look exponential still). When looking at confirmed cases as a proportion of population, Africa is where Asia was a month ago (which is seeing a doubling time of 70 days, but isn't a helpful comparison). The same comparison method would suggest Africa is where Europe was on March 26th (267,000 confirmed cases), whose case numbers have grown by nearly an order of magnitude in 3 months. Obviously, numbers are still growing, but I'm going to naively assume there will be a 10x growth (like Europe experienced) in the next few months as a minimum. That gives >4 million cases. Same comparison has South America in this position by April 29th. South America is probably more comparable to Africa than any other continent, and they've had case numbers grow 15x in just 2 months! And things are still getting rapidly worse. I'm going to take 20x current case numbers as the median for Africa, and will update as I see how South America progresses (I think things will turn out worse there than they do in Africa, though). 80% confidence interval = [4 mil, 8 mil, 18 mil] [Africa is a young continent and, while there may be confounding factors that reduce their resilience to the virus, I expect the mortality rate to be lower here than in the UK, for example. So they may not become worried about it (and not test as much) but I doubt this reasoning is helpful to think through. I'm not sure how age affects transmissibility.]
